moves.1. c4 f5 2. g4: This is the gambit move. It's not a "pure" Krejcik, which properly arises after 1. d4 f5  2. g4, so perhaps this specific configuration should be called the Krejcik Gambit System or (pardon the shameless self-promotion) the "Avocet Gambit."  ;-)
moves.2... d5: Interesting. In many gambits Black's "correct answer" features ...d5 at some point, usually quickly after the gambit move.
moves.3. Bg2 c6: If 3. ...dc4 then 4.Qa4 --> Qc4 is a plausible response.
moves.4. cxd5 cxd5 5. gxf5 Bxf5 6. d3 Nf6 7. Q: Now everyone's pawns are bad ...but White's are just a little better.
moves.13. Qc3 Nc6: Of course. There is no other square for the Knight to retreat to except the one it just came from.
moves.14. Rc1 Bd6 15. Bg3 Bxg3 16. hxg3: Now White's pawns look even better.
Maintaining the pawn-strength in the center.
moves.26... Ke7 27. f4 Nh5 28. Kf2 Ke6 29. Nc4: ?! -- Good idea, wrong moment. This should have been prepared-for with Bf3 threatening to snap off the h5N at an opportune moment, or 29. e5 followed by Bf3, and *then* Nc4.
moves.29... Nb1 30. Ke3: ?? -- Nothing but a blunder. Better was 30. a4.
moves.30... b5 31. Ne5: This was the idea behind Nc4, to win Black's K-side pawns. But my previous blunder, hanging two pawns, had me pretty depressed at this point; I was just about ready to resign.
moves.31... Nxa3: However, that was the wrong pawn to take. White's a-pawn isn't going anywhere, and ... Ng3 captures with tempo.
moves.32. g4 Nf6 33. Nxg6: ? -- Still trying to lose. Instead, an immediate 33. g5 had a nasty little bite to it, without dropping a pawn.
moves.33... Nxg4+ 34. Kd4 a5 35. e5 Kf5: ?? -- Amazingly this rather natural-looking move almost loses by force. The correct move was 35. ...Nh6.
moves.36... Ke6 37. f5+ Kf7 38. e6+: Chessplayers have a tendency to forget that in conjunction with marching pawns, the Bishop-Knight tandem can be a powerful attacking duo.
moves.38... Ke8: ?? -- Loses instantly. The correct move was 38. ...Kg8!! which looks awful but seems a hard nut to crack. In fact, White may have no better than a perpetual with 39. Ne7 Kf8  40. Ng6 etc.
moves.39. Bc6+: Black resigns. 39. ...Kd8  40. e7+ Kc7  41. e8=Q as too much.
